awd_titl_txt: Nature-Based Solutions for Restoring Rivers and Streams
awd_abstract_narration:
Rivers and streams are a key component of the global ecosystem. Human alteration and pollution have made many of them no longer able to provide full ecological services and functions. In recent years, substantial efforts have been invested in restoring rivers and streams to improve their health, promote biodiversity, and increase resiliency. Among many restoration solutions, those mimicking how Nature works are increasingly employed, e.g., the re-introduction of wood into rivers and streams. However, the knowledge base for these nature-based solutions can be enhanced by improved scientific understanding on the physical processes around restoration structures. A principal objective of this research is to improve the knowledge base for nature-based approaches for river and steam restoration. 

The research approach to be used in this work utilizes state-of- the-art computing technology which makes it feasible to resolve the complex geometry of the restoration structures. It is anticipated that this project will reveal the physical processes around and within restoration structures. The understanding of physical processes is critical to successful implementation of nature-based solutions. Ecologically functional rivers and streams add great socio-economic value to the communities living around them.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Healthy rivers and streams are essential for biodiversity, clean water, and community well-being. In recent years, river restoration efforts have increasingly turned to nature-based solutions - using natural materials like wood to mimic how rivers function in the wild. One popular approach is the use of Engineered Log Jams (ELJs), which are carefully constructed piles of wood placed in rivers to slow water, reduce erosion, and create habitats for fish and other aquatic life.

This project aimed to improve scientific understanding of how these wood-based restoration structures work, particularly focusing on how porosity - the amount of space between logs -affects water flow and sediment movement. We hypothesized that porous structures reduce the erosion (or scour) around them in a predictable, scale-independent way. This insight could help engineers design better, more reliable restoration structures.

To test this idea, we combined advanced computer modeling with laboratory experiments. Using the open-source computational fluid dynamics (CFD) platform called OpenFOAM, we developed a high-resolution model that can simulate water and sediment moving through and around complex log jam structures. This model was validated through a series of experiments in a large flume at Penn State, where scaled-down versions of log jams were built and tested under various flow conditions.

Our findings confirmed that porosity significantly influences sediment transport and scour, and we were able to propose a new, improved formula to predict scour depth based on structure porosity. This is a major step forward, as current engineering tools do not fully account for porosity and often overestimate erosion. Importantly, our results were also supported by field data from a real-world restoration site in Washington State, confirming the broader applicability of our findings.

Beyond the technical contributions, this project had strong educational and outreach components. Undergraduate and graduate students gained more experiences and exposure to river restoration and nature-based solutions. They had the chance to visit the hydraulics lab at Penn State and observed flume experiments during this project. We also shared our results with practitioners and researchers through presentations at the ASCE Environmental and Water Resources Institute (EWRI) conferences and AGU Fall Meetings.

In summary, this project advanced our understanding of how nature-based river restoration structures function hydrodynamically and geomorphologically, developed new tools and models for researchers and engineers, and enriched learning experiences for students. By bridging the gap between science and practice, this work helps ensure that future river restoration efforts are more effective, resilient, and based on sound science.
